body:
The only point at which the internal `delivery_count` property of a pending message is incremented is in `streamReplyWithRangeFromConsumerPEL`, which is called response to an `XREADGROUP` with an `ID` other than `>`.

The [XLAIM docs](https://redis.io/commands/xclaim) say:

> Moreover, as a side effect, XCLAIM will increment the count of attempted deliveries of the message. In this way messages that cannot be processed for some reason, for instance because the consumers crash attempting to process them, will start to have a larger counter and can be detected inside the system.

This would be useful and is exactly the functionality I'm looking for - since I'm not using `JUSTID` I don't need the consumer to fetch the message again since I already have the full message in the response - but this isn't actually what happens. The only way the `delivery_count` property gets updated as a result of calling `XREADGROUP` is if `RETRYCOUNT` is specified but that sets it to an explicit value rather than increments it.

I can work around what I want by manually passing `RETRYCOUNT` myself, but either the code or the documentation should be updated so that this isn't surprising behaviour.

On reflection, I wonder if this was an intentional change to support third party processes reallocating pending messages to consumers (rather than consumers claiming them themselves). In those cases, just because `XCLAIM` was called to reallocate a message to a specific consumer doesn't mean the message was delivered to that consumer. 

In the above model, it makes sense to increment the delivery only when the consumer fetches its own pending messages using `XREADGROUP ... 0`. That said, my assumption would be that most implementations would have consumers claim pending messages themselves so the documented behaviour of `XCLAIM` makes the most sense to me.

issue.title: Increment delivery counter on XCLAIM unless RETRYCOUNT specified

labels.name: IMPORTANT
labels.description: This issue is important and should be checked often

repository.name: redis
repository.description: For developers, who are building real-time data-driven applications, Redis is the preferred, fastest, and most feature-rich cache, data structure server, and document and vector query engine.

issue.body:
The [`XCLAIM` docs](https://redis.io/commands/xclaim) state:

> Moreover, as a side effect, **XCLAIM will increment the count of attempted deliveries of the message**. In this way messages that cannot be processed for some reason, for instance because the consumers crash attempting to process them, will start to have a larger counter and can be detected inside the system.

This PR makes the code match the documentation - with added semantics for `JUSTID` - whilst still allowing `RETRYCOUNT` to be specified manually. A [separate PR](antirez/redis-doc#1093) has been opened for clarifying documentation

My understanding of the way `streamPropagateXCLAIM()` works is that this change will safely propagate to replicas since retry count is pulled directly from the `streamNACK` struct.

Fixes #5194

body: Hello, all this makes sense, but I wonder why in the PR to fix the issue kindly provided by @spjwebster the counter is incremented even if JUSTID is given. Thanks.

@antirez my intent was to match the documented behaviour, which doesn't mention any precondition based on `JUSTID`. To me it seems like this is the least surprising implementation - to have claiming count as receiving delivery. My assumption is that if the consumer is using `JUSTID` they already have the message data through `XRANGE` or similar, but I'm happy to alter and open a separate docs PR to clarify if that more closely matches your original intent.

FWIW, for our usecase - having consumers check for and consume lapsed pending messages before going into a blocking `XREADGROUP` call - I'm not using the `JUSTID` option.
Any further thoughts on this @antirez? We've got a workaround for now but it would be great to get this or a modified version that honours the `JUSTID` semantics, into redis core.

@spjwebster Hello, sorry I was traveling, back at home finally. Yes I would love if you could alter PR and doc if possible, because I think that it is sensible if we increment the count every time we *deliver* the message. JUSTID use case is also when the worker want just to check and maybe later fetch the messages. I think both the documentation and the code where wrong in that case compared to what I had in mind :-D Thanks!

issue.title: Clarify that JUSTID option doesn't increment delivery count

repository.name: redis-doc
repository.description: Redis documentation source code for markdown and metadata files, conversion scripts, and so forth

issue.body: See antirez/redis#5194 for discussion on `JUSTID` semantics. Goes hand in hand with antirez/redis#5907 which embodies this logic.

body: Thanks @antirez. I've updated the PR to honour the `JUSTID` sematics and opened a separate PR against redis-docs to amend the documentation. Shout if you need anything else.

This is again not working AFAICT in Redis 5.0.5
https://github.com/antirez/redis/blob/c696aebdbab4b84087a0acfdab627fcd2317c3b5/src/t_stream.c#L2284

```
redis:6379> xclaim mystream mygroup c 0 1564713742264-0
1) 1) "1564713742264-0"
   2) 1) "a"
      2) "\"b\""
      3) "c"
      4) "\"d\""
redis:6379> "xpending" "mystream" "mygroup "-" "+" "1" c
1) 1) "1564713742264-0"
   2) "c"
   3) (integer) 3032
   4) (integer) 2
redis:6379> xclaim mystream mygroup c 0 1564713742264-0
1) 1) "1564713742264-0"
   2) 1) "a"
      2) "\"b\""
      3) "c"
      4) "\"d\""
redis:6379> "xpending" "mystream" "mygroup" "-" "+" "1" c
1) 1) "1564713742264-0"
   2) "c"
   3) (integer) 648
   4) (integer) 2
```

I see some workarounds to achieve BOTH lastReadAgo reset and tries counter increment:
1) Use `xclaim` with `justid`, and follow it by an `xreadgroup` request for that one `ID`, or;
2) Use `xpending` to view last tries counter value, and follow it with `xclaim` `RETRYCOUNT` setting it to +1 what you last saw, manually (not thread-safe, so be certain only one client is attempting this)
3) If recovering your own consumer id messages post-crash, `xreadgroup` with `COUNT 1` and `ID` of `0` gives your oldest pending message while incrementing tries and resetting lastReadAgo, and then `xpending` for that specific `ID` will tell you what those values are.
